cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Which is the only element, from the group known as the Halogens, which is liquid at room temperature?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
1. The halogens are a group of elements found in Group 17 of the periodic table. They include fluorine (F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br), iodine (I), and astatine (At).
2. To determine which halogen is liquid at room temperature, we need to consider the physical states of these elements at 20-25 degrees Celsius (room temperature).
3. Fluorine and chlorine are gases at room temperature, while iodine and astatine are solids.
4. Bromine is the only halogen that is a liquid at room temperature, with a melting point of about -7.2 degrees Celsius and a boiling point of about 58.8 degrees Celsius.

Answer:
Bromine (Br) is the only halogen that is liquid at room temperature.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Which is the only element, from the group known as the Halogens, which is liquid at room temperature?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Only two elements are liquid at standard conditions for temperature and pressure: mercury and bromine. Four more elements have melting points slightly above room temperature: francium, caesium, gallium and rubidium. Metal alloys that are liquid at room temperature include NaK, a sodium-potassium metal alloy, galinstan, a fusible alloy liquid, and some amalgams (alloys involving mercury).\n', 'The "water" radical () is rarely used, since only two elements (bromine and mercury) are truly liquid at standard room temperature and pressure. Both of their characters are not based on the European pronunciation of the elements\' names. Bromine (), the only liquid nonmetal at room temperature, is explained in the following section. Mercury (), now grouped with the heavy metals, was long classified as a kind of fluid in ancient China.\n', 'The only chemical elements that are stable single atom molecules at standard temperature and pressure (STP) are the noble gases. These are helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon and radon. Noble gases have a full outer valence shell making them rather non-reactive species. While these elements have been described historically as completely inert, chemical compounds have been synthesized with all but neon and helium.\n', 'Water () is a polar inorganic compound that is at room temperature a tasteless and odorless liquid, nearly colorless with a hint of blue. This simplest hydrogen chalcogenide is by far the most studied chemical compound and is described as the "universal solvent" for its ability to dissolve many substances. This allows it to be the "solvent of life". It is the only common substance to exist as a solid, liquid, and gas in normal terrestrial conditions.\n', 'Another commonly used basic distinction among the elements is their state of matter (phase), whether solid, liquid, or gas, at a selected standard temperature and pressure (STP). Most of the elements are solids at conventional temperatures and atmospheric pressure, while several are gases. Only bromine and mercury are liquids at 0 degrees Celsius (32 degrees Fahrenheit) and normal atmospheric pressure; caesium and gallium are solids at that temperature, but melt at 28.4\xa0°C (83.2\xa0°F) and 29.8\xa0°C (85.6\xa0°F), respectively.\n', 'BULLET::::- NaK, Mercury - other metals which are liquid at room temperature\n', 'Though often placed at the top of the alkali metal column in the periodic table, hydrogen does not, under ordinary conditions, exhibit the properties of an alkali metal. Instead, it forms diatomic molecules, analogous to halogens and non-metals in the second row of the periodic table, such as nitrogen and oxygen. Diatomic hydrogen is a gas that, at atmospheric pressure, liquefies and solidifies only at very low temperature (20 degrees and 14 degrees above absolute zero, respectively). Eugene Wigner and Hillard Bell Huntington predicted that under an immense pressure of around hydrogen would display metallic properties: instead of discrete molecules (which consist of two electrons bound between two protons), a bulk phase would form with a solid lattice of protons and the electrons delocalized throughout. Since then, producing metallic hydrogen in the laboratory has been described as "...the holy grail of high-pressure physics."\n', "Given the great reactivity of atomic nitrogen, elemental nitrogen usually occurs as molecular N, dinitrogen. This molecule is a colourless, odourless, and tasteless diamagnetic gas at standard conditions: it melts at −210\xa0°C and boils at −196\xa0°C. Dinitrogen is mostly unreactive at room temperature, but it will nevertheless react with lithium metal and some transition metal complexes. This is due to its bonding, which is unique among the diatomic elements at standard conditions in that it has an N≡N triple bond. Triple bonds have short bond lengths (in this case, 109.76\xa0pm) and high dissociation energies (in this case, 945.41\xa0kJ/mol), and are thus very strong, explaining dinitrogen's chemical inertness.\n", 'The element hydrogen, with one electron per neutral atom, is usually placed at the top of Group 1 of the periodic table for convenience, but hydrogen is not normally considered to be an alkali metal; when it is considered to be an alkali metal, it is because of its atomic properties and not its chemical properties. Under typical conditions, pure hydrogen exists as a diatomic gas consisting of two atoms per molecule (H); however, the alkali metals only form diatomic molecules (such as dilithium, Li) at high temperatures, when they are in the gaseous state.\n', 'Hydrogen (H) is the chemical element with atomic number 1. At standard temperature and pressure, hydrogen is a colorless, odorless, nonmetallic, tasteless, highly flammable diatomic gas with the molecular formula H. With an atomic mass of 1.00794\xa0amu, hydrogen is the lightest element.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question regarding which halogen is the only element that is liquid at room temperature, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. 

### Relevant Extracted Content:

1. **Liquid Elements at Room Temperature**:
   - "Only two elements are liquid at standard conditions for temperature and pressure: mercury and bromine."
   - "The only liquid nonmetal at room temperature is bromine."

2. **Properties of Bromine**:
   - "Bromine, the only liquid nonmetal at room temperature, is explained in the following section."
   - "Only bromine and mercury are liquids at 0 degrees Celsius (32 degrees Fahrenheit) and normal atmospheric pressure."

3. **Comparison with Other Elements**:
   - "Caesium and gallium are solids at that temperature, but melt at 28.4 °C (83.2 °F) and 29.8 °C (85.6 °F), respectively."

### Analysis of the Extracted Content:

1. **Identification of Bromine**:
   - The passages explicitly state that bromine is the only liquid nonmetal at room temperature, which directly answers the question. This is crucial information as it highlights bromine's unique status among the halogens.

2. **Context of Liquid Elements**:
   - The mention of mercury alongside bromine provides context that while both are liquids at room temperature, mercury is a metal, whereas bromine is a nonmetal. This distinction is important in understanding the classification of elements.

3. **Temperature Reference**:
   - The passages provide specific temperature references (0 degrees Celsius and the melting points of caesium and gallium) that help establish the conditions under which bromine remains liquid. This contextualizes the information and reinforces the understanding of "room temperature."

4. **Comparison with Other Elements**:
   - The comparison with caesium and gallium, which are solids at room temperature but have melting points just above it, emphasizes the uniqueness of bromine's state at standard conditions. This helps clarify why bromine is notable among the halogens.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content effectively informs the model about the specific characteristics of bromine as the only liquid halogen at room temperature. It provides necessary context regarding the state of matter of other elements and reinforces the understanding of temperature conditions that define "room temperature." This background knowledge is essential for accurately answering the question posed.

Generation Format:
knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

1. **Understanding Halogens**:
   - The halogens are a group of elements located in Group 17 of the periodic table, which includes fluorine (F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br), iodine (I), and astatine (At). They are known for their high reactivity and tendency to form salts with metals.

2. **Physical States at Room Temperature**:
   - To determine which halogen is liquid at room temperature (approximately 20-25 degrees Celsius), we examine the physical states of these elements:
     - **Fluorine (F)**: Gas at room temperature.
     - **Chlorine (Cl)**: Gas at room temperature.
     - **Bromine (Br)**: Liquid at room temperature, with a melting point of about -7.2 degrees Celsius and a boiling point of about 58.8 degrees Celsius.
     - **Iodine (I)**: Solid at room temperature.
     - **Astatine (At)**: Solid at room temperature, though its properties are less well-studied due to its radioactivity.

3. **Unique Properties of Bromine**:
   - Bromine is the only liquid nonmetal at room temperature, which distinguishes it from the other halogens. This characteristic is significant because it highlights bromine's unique physical state compared to its gaseous and solid counterparts.

4. **Context of Liquid Elements**:
   - It is important to note that while bromine is a liquid, mercury is also a liquid at room temperature. However, mercury is a metal, which further emphasizes bromine's distinction as the only liquid nonmetal in the halogen group.

5. **Comparison with Other Elements**:
   - The melting points of caesium and gallium, which are solids at room temperature but have melting points just above it (28.4 °C and 29.8 °C, respectively), provide context for understanding bromine's state. This comparison reinforces the idea that bromine remains liquid under standard conditions, unlike these other elements.

### Conclusion:
The enhanced reasoning process clarifies that bromine is the only halogen that exists as a liquid at room temperature, providing a comprehensive understanding of its unique properties and context within the periodic table.

### Answer:
Bromine (Br) is the only halogen that is liquid at room temperature.

Task Description:

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. Identify points of agreement and disagreement among the experts, and analyze how these differing perspectives contribute to a deeper understanding of the topic. Synthesize the insights from the discussion into a cohesive summary that captures the full range of foundational and advanced knowledge. Highlight how these perspectives expand the understanding of the question.

By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on Halogens and Liquid Elements at Room Temperature**

**Expert 1: The Chemist**
The Chemist begins by emphasizing that bromine is the only liquid nonmetal at room temperature. This is supported by the passages that clearly state bromine's unique position among the halogens. The Chemist points out that while mercury is also a liquid at room temperature, it is not a halogen, thus reinforcing that bromine stands alone in this category.

**Expert 2: The Physicist**
The Physicist agrees with the Chemist but adds a layer of complexity by discussing the physical properties of bromine. They highlight that bromine's liquid state at room temperature is due to its relatively low melting point compared to other halogens. The Physicist mentions that the other halogens—fluorine, chlorine, iodine, and astatine—are all gases or solids at room temperature, which further underscores bromine's uniqueness.

**Expert 3: The Historian**
The Historian brings a historical perspective, noting that the classification of elements has evolved over time. They mention that mercury was historically grouped with nonmetals due to its fluidity, which may lead to confusion. However, they agree that in the context of halogens, bromine is the only liquid. This historical context helps to clarify why there might be misconceptions about the states of various elements.

**Expert 4: The Material Scientist**
The Material Scientist focuses on the implications of bromine's liquid state for practical applications. They discuss how bromine is used in various chemical processes and materials, such as flame retardants and pharmaceuticals. This perspective highlights the importance of understanding the physical state of elements in real-world applications.

**Points of Agreement and Disagreement**
All experts agree that bromine is the only liquid halogen at room temperature. They also concur that mercury, while a liquid at room temperature, does not belong to the halogen group. The disagreement arises in the emphasis on the implications of bromine's state: while the Chemist and Physicist focus on its chemical properties, the Material Scientist emphasizes practical applications.

**Synthesis of Insights**
The discussion reveals a comprehensive understanding of bromine's unique status among the halogens. Bromine's liquid state at room temperature is not only a chemical curiosity but also has significant implications for its use in various industries. The historical context provided by the Historian enriches the understanding of how classifications can change over time, which is crucial for interpreting scientific literature.

In summary, bromine is recognized as the only liquid halogen at room temperature, with mercury being a notable liquid element that is not part of this group. The insights from the experts collectively enhance the understanding of bromine's properties, applications, and the historical evolution of elemental classification. This multifaceted perspective underscores the importance of considering both chemical properties and practical applications in the study of elements.

This practical perspective reinforces the importance of understanding the physical states of elements beyond mere classification.

6. **Consensus Among Experts**: All experts agree on bromine's unique position as the only liquid halogen at room temperature, while also recognizing mercury's status as a liquid that is not part of the halogen group. The differing emphases on chemical properties, historical context, and practical applications enrich the overall understanding of bromine.

**Answer**:  
Bromine (Br) is the only halogen that is liquid at room temperature.

   - Specifically, one passage states: "Bromine (), the only liquid nonmetal at room temperature..." This indicates that bromine is a halogen and is unique among nonmetals for being liquid at room temperature.

2. **Comparison with Other Elements**:
   - Other elements like caesium and gallium have melting points just above room temperature but are not liquids at room temperature. This distinction is important as it clarifies that while some elements can be liquid near room temperature, they do not qualify as liquids at standard room temperature.

3. **Context of Halogens**:
   - The halogens include fluorine, chlorine, bromine, iodine, and astatine. Among these, bromine is highlighted as the only liquid at room temperature, reinforcing its unique status within the group.

### Consolidation of Information:
From the passages, we can consolidate the following points:
- Bromine is the only liquid nonmetal at room temperature.
- Mercury is also liquid at room temperature but is not a halogen.
- Other elements may be close to being liquid but do not meet the criteria for being liquid at room temperature.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Causal Relationships**: Understanding the properties of elements (like state of matter at specific temperatures) helps in establishing causal relationships. For example, knowing that bromine is a halogen and is liquid at room temperature allows one to infer that it has unique properties compared to other halogens.

2. **Logical Classification**: The information helps in logically classifying elements based on their states at room temperature, which is crucial for scientific reasoning. This classification can lead to further inquiries about the properties of halogens and their applications.

3. **Critical Thinking**: By analyzing the distinctions between elements that are liquid at room temperature versus those that are not, the model can enhance its critical thinking skills. It learns to differentiate based on specific criteria, which is a fundamental aspect of logical reasoning.

4. **Contextual Understanding**: The passages provide context about the periodic table and the classification of elements, which can aid in understanding broader scientific concepts. This contextual knowledge is essential for making informed inferences about chemical behavior and properties.

In summary, the extracted information from the passages enhances the model's ability to reason causally and logically by providing clear distinctions, classifications, and contextual understanding of the properties of elements, particularly within the halogen group. This can lead to improved reasoning capabilities in scientific contexts.

question:
Which is the only element, from the group known as the Halogens, which is liquid at room temperature?
answer:
Reasoning process:
1. The halogens are a group of elements found in Group 17 of the periodic table. They include fluorine (F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br), iodine (I), and astatine (At).
2. To determine which halogen is liquid at room temperature, we need to consider the physical states of these elements at 20-25 degrees Celsius (room temperature).
3. Fluorine and chlorine are gases at room temperature, while iodine and astatine are solids.
4. Bromine is the only halogen that is a liquid at room temperature, with a melting point of about -7.2 degrees Celsius and a boiling point of about 58.8 degrees Celsius.

Answer:
Bromine (Br) is the only halogen that is liquid at room temperature.

To address the question of which halogen is the only element that is liquid at room temperature, we can extract relevant information from the provided passages. The key points to focus on are:

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Causal Relationships**: Understanding the properties of elements (like state of matter at specific temperatures) helps in establishing causal relationships. knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

1. **Understanding Halogens**: The halogens are a group of elements located in Group 17 of the periodic table, which includes fluorine (F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br), iodine (I), and astatine (At). Each of these elements has distinct physical and chemical properties.

2. **Physical States at Room Temperature**: To determine which halogen is liquid at room temperature (approximately 20-25 degrees Celsius), we analyze the physical states of each halogen:
   - **Fluorine (F)**: Gas at room temperature.
   - **Chlorine (Cl)**: Gas at room temperature.
   - **Bromine (Br)**: Liquid at room temperature, with a melting point of about -7.2 degrees Celsius and a boiling point of about 58.8 degrees Celsius.
   - **Iodine (I)**: Solid at room temperature.
   - **Astatine (At)**: Solid at room temperature, though its properties are less well-characterized due to its radioactivity.

3. **Unique Characteristics of Bromine**: Bromine is the only halogen that exists as a liquid under standard conditions. This unique property distinguishes it from the other halogens, which are either gases or solids at room temperature.

4. **Comparison with Other Elements**: While mercury is also a liquid at room temperature, it is not a halogen. Other elements like caesium and gallium have melting points just above room temperature but do not remain liquid at standard conditions.

5. **Causal Relationships**: Understanding the states of matter for these elements at room temperature allows us to establish causal relationships regarding their physical properties. For instance, bromine's unique state as a liquid at room temperature can be attributed to its molecular structure and intermolecular forces.

6. **Logical Classification and Critical Thinking**: The classification of bromine as a liquid halogen enhances logical reasoning by providing a clear distinction between the states of different elements. This classification can lead to further inquiries about the implications of bromine's liquid state, such as its reactivity and applications in various chemical processes.

7. **Contextual Understanding**: The context of the periodic table and the classification of elements is crucial for understanding broader scientific concepts. This knowledge aids in making informed inferences about the behavior and properties of halogens and their interactions with other elements.

### Answer:
Bromine (Br) is the only halogen that is liquid at room temperature.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
Which is the only element, from the group known as the Halogens, which is liquid at room temperature?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Only two elements are liquid at standard conditions for temperature and pressure: mercury and bromine. Four more elements have melting points slightly above room temperature: francium, caesium, gallium and rubidium. Metal alloys that are liquid at room temperature include NaK, a sodium-potassium metal alloy, galinstan, a fusible alloy liquid, and some amalgams (alloys involving mercury).\n', 'The "water" radical () is rarely used, since only two elements (bromine and mercury) are truly liquid at standard room temperature and pressure. Both of their characters are not based on the European pronunciation of the elements\' names. Bromine (), the only liquid nonmetal at room temperature, is explained in the following section. Mercury (), now grouped with the heavy metals, was long classified as a kind of fluid in ancient China.\n', 'The only chemical elements that are stable single atom molecules at standard temperature and pressure (STP) are the noble gases. These are helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon and radon. Noble gases have a full outer valence shell making them rather non-reactive species. While these elements have been described historically as completely inert, chemical compounds have been synthesized with all but neon and helium.\n', 'Water () is a polar inorganic compound that is at room temperature a tasteless and odorless liquid, nearly colorless with a hint of blue. This simplest hydrogen chalcogenide is by far the most studied chemical compound and is described as the "universal solvent" for its ability to dissolve many substances. This allows it to be the "solvent of life". It is the only common substance to exist as a solid, liquid, and gas in normal terrestrial conditions.\n', 'Another commonly used basic distinction among the elements is their state of matter (phase), whether solid, liquid, or gas, at a selected standard temperature and pressure (STP). Most of the elements are solids at conventional temperatures and atmospheric pressure, while several are gases. Only bromine and mercury are liquids at 0 degrees Celsius (32 degrees Fahrenheit) and normal atmospheric pressure; caesium and gallium are solids at that temperature, but melt at 28.4\xa0°C (83.2\xa0°F) and 29.8\xa0°C (85.6\xa0°F), respectively.\n', 'BULLET::::- NaK, Mercury - other metals which are liquid at room temperature\n', 'Though often placed at the top of the alkali metal column in the periodic table, hydrogen does not, under ordinary conditions, exhibit the properties of an alkali metal. Instead, it forms diatomic molecules, analogous to halogens and non-metals in the second row of the periodic table, such as nitrogen and oxygen. Diatomic hydrogen is a gas that, at atmospheric pressure, liquefies and solidifies only at very low temperature (20 degrees and 14 degrees above absolute zero, respectively). Eugene Wigner and Hillard Bell Huntington predicted that under an immense pressure of around hydrogen would display metallic properties: instead of discrete molecules (which consist of two electrons bound between two protons), a bulk phase would form with a solid lattice of protons and the electrons delocalized throughout. Since then, producing metallic hydrogen in the laboratory has been described as "...the holy grail of high-pressure physics."\n', "Given the great reactivity of atomic nitrogen, elemental nitrogen usually occurs as molecular N, dinitrogen. This molecule is a colourless, odourless, and tasteless diamagnetic gas at standard conditions: it melts at −210\xa0°C and boils at −196\xa0°C. Dinitrogen is mostly unreactive at room temperature, but it will nevertheless react with lithium metal and some transition metal complexes. This is due to its bonding, which is unique among the diatomic elements at standard conditions in that it has an N≡N triple bond. Triple bonds have short bond lengths (in this case, 109.76\xa0pm) and high dissociation energies (in this case, 945.41\xa0kJ/mol), and are thus very strong, explaining dinitrogen's chemical inertness.\n", 'The element hydrogen, with one electron per neutral atom, is usually placed at the top of Group 1 of the periodic table for convenience, but hydrogen is not normally considered to be an alkali metal; when it is considered to be an alkali metal, it is because of its atomic properties and not its chemical properties. Under typical conditions, pure hydrogen exists as a diatomic gas consisting of two atoms per molecule (H); however, the alkali metals only form diatomic molecules (such as dilithium, Li) at high temperatures, when they are in the gaseous state.\n', 'Hydrogen (H) is the chemical element with atomic number 1. At standard temperature and pressure, hydrogen is a colorless, odorless, nonmetallic, tasteless, highly flammable diatomic gas with the molecular formula H. With an atomic mass of 1.00794\xa0amu, hydrogen is the lightest element.\n']

Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

1. **Understanding Halogens**: The halogens are a group of elements located in Group 17 of the periodic table, which includes fluorine (F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br), iodine (I), and astatine (At). 

2. **Physical States at Room Temperature**: To identify which halogen is liquid at room temperature (approximately 20-25 degrees Celsius), we examine the physical states of these elements:
   - Fluorine (F) and chlorine (Cl) are gases at room temperature.
   - Iodine (I) and astatine (At) are solids at room temperature.
   - Bromine (Br) is the only halogen that is a liquid at room temperature, with a melting point of about -7.2 degrees Celsius and a boiling point of about 58.8 degrees Celsius.

3. **Clarification on Liquid Elements**: While mercury is also a liquid at room temperature, it is important to note that it is not a halogen; it belongs to the category of heavy metals. This distinction is crucial to avoid any confusion regarding the classification of elements.

4. **Other Elements and Their States**: The passages highlight that there are other elements, such as gallium and caesium, which can be liquid at temperatures slightly above room temperature. However, these elements are not halogens and do not remain liquid at standard room temperature.

5. **Standard Conditions**: The passages consistently refer to standard temperature and pressure (STP) when discussing the states of matter for these elements, reinforcing the importance of these conditions in determining the state of an element.

6. **Conclusion**: Based on the information retrieved, it is clear that bromine is the only liquid halogen at room temperature. This knowledge helps to clarify the properties of halogens and ensures accurate representation in the model.

**Answer**: Bromine (Br) is the only halogen that is liquid at room temperature.

question_info.question: Which is the only element, from the group known as the Halogens, which is liquid at room temperature?
passages:
Only two elements are liquid at standard conditions for temperature and pressure: mercury and bromine. Four more elements have melting points slightly above room temperature: francium, caesium, gallium and rubidium. Metal alloys that are liquid at room temperature include NaK, a sodium-potassium metal alloy, galinstan, a fusible alloy liquid, and some amalgams (alloys involving mercury).
The "water" radical () is rarely used, since only two elements (bromine and mercury) are truly liquid at standard room temperature and pressure. Both of their characters are not based on the European pronunciation of the elements' names. Bromine (), the only liquid nonmetal at room temperature, is explained in the following section. Mercury (), now grouped with the heavy metals, was long classified as a kind of fluid in ancient China.
The only chemical elements that are stable single atom molecules at standard temperature and pressure (STP) are the noble gases. These are helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon and radon. Noble gases have a full outer valence shell making them rather non-reactive species. While these elements have been described historically as completely inert, chemical compounds have been synthesized with all but neon and helium.
Water () is a polar inorganic compound that is at room temperature a tasteless and odorless liquid, nearly colorless with a hint of blue. This simplest hydrogen chalcogenide is by far the most studied chemical compound and is described as the "universal solvent" for its ability to dissolve many substances. This allows it to be the "solvent of life". It is the only common substance to exist as a solid, liquid, and gas in normal terrestrial conditions.
Another commonly used basic distinction among the elements is their state of matter (phase), whether solid, liquid, or gas, at a selected standard temperature and pressure (STP). Most of the elements are solids at conventional temperatures and atmospheric pressure, while several are gases. Only bromine and mercury are liquids at 0 degrees Celsius (32 degrees Fahrenheit) and normal atmospheric pressure; caesium and gallium are solids at that temperature, but melt at 28.4 °C (83.2 °F) and 29.8 °C (85.6 °F), respectively.
BULLET::::- NaK, Mercury - other metals which are liquid at room temperature
Though often placed at the top of the alkali metal column in the periodic table, hydrogen does not, under ordinary conditions, exhibit the properties of an alkali metal. Instead, it forms diatomic molecules, analogous to halogens and non-metals in the second row of the periodic table, such as nitrogen and oxygen. Diatomic hydrogen is a gas that, at atmospheric pressure, liquefies and solidifies only at very low temperature (20 degrees and 14 degrees above absolute zero, respectively). Eugene Wigner and Hillard Bell Huntington predicted that under an immense pressure of around hydrogen would display metallic properties: instead of discrete molecules (which consist of two electrons bound between two protons), a bulk phase would form with a solid lattice of protons and the electrons delocalized throughout. Since then, producing metallic hydrogen in the laboratory has been described as "...the holy grail of high-pressure physics."
Given the great reactivity of atomic nitrogen, elemental nitrogen usually occurs as molecular N, dinitrogen. This molecule is a colourless, odourless, and tasteless diamagnetic gas at standard conditions: it melts at −210 °C and boils at −196 °C. Dinitrogen is mostly unreactive at room temperature, but it will nevertheless react with lithium metal and some transition metal complexes. This is due to its bonding, which is unique among the diatomic elements at standard conditions in that it has an N≡N triple bond. Triple bonds have short bond lengths (in this case, 109.76 pm) and high dissociation energies (in this case, 945.41 kJ/mol), and are thus very strong, explaining dinitrogen's chemical inertness.
The element hydrogen, with one electron per neutral atom, is usually placed at the top of Group 1 of the periodic table for convenience, but hydrogen is not normally considered to be an alkali metal; when it is considered to be an alkali metal, it is because of its atomic properties and not its chemical properties. Under typical conditions, pure hydrogen exists as a diatomic gas consisting of two atoms per molecule (H); however, the alkali metals only form diatomic molecules (such as dilithium, Li) at high temperatures, when they are in the gaseous state.
Hydrogen (H) is the chemical element with atomic number 1. At standard temperature and pressure, hydrogen is a colorless, odorless, nonmetallic, tasteless, highly flammable diatomic gas with the molecular formula H. With an atomic mass of 1.00794 amu, hydrogen is the lightest element.
